nodes.text: Forced compliance (being induced to state or perform something contrary to private opinion) will produce private opinion change toward the overt behavior, and the smaller the external inducement beyond minimum required, the greater the opinion change

Theoretical derivation from cognitive dissonance: dissonance magnitude is inversely related to the sum of consonant pressures (e.g., larger rewards reduce dissonance), and dissonance reduction can occur by changing private opinion to match public statement

Laboratory method: 71 male introductory psychology students did two boring tasks, then were placed in one of three conditions (Control, One Dollar, Twenty Dollars); in One Dollar and Twenty Dollar they were asked to tell a waiting subject the tasks were enjoyable and were paid accordingly; private opinions were later measured in an unrelated interview using four scaled questions; conversations were secretly recorded
Prediction tested: larger reward beyond minimum needed will produce smaller subsequent opinion change compared to smaller reward

Result on primary measure (how enjoyable tasks were): Control mean = -0.45, One Dollar mean = +1.35 (significantly higher than Control, p approx 0.02), Twenty Dollar mean = -0.05 (not significantly different from Control); One Dollar vs Twenty Dollar difference significant (p approx 0.03)

Result on desire to participate in a similar experiment: means directionally parallel to enjoyment measure (Control = -0.62, One Dollar = +1.20, Twenty Dollars = -0.25) but differences weaker and only marginally significant (One Dollar vs Control p approx 0.08)
Result on perceived scientific importance: One Dollar higher than Twenty Dollar (difference marginal, p approx 0.08); One Dollar vs Control not significant
Result on how much subjects learned: no reliable differences among conditions (means around 2.8 to 3.15 on 0-10 scale), indicating effect specificity to dissonance-relevant content

Evidence against alternative 'self-rehearsal' explanation: taped conversations were transcribed and rated blind on content, persuasiveness, and time spent; ratings show Twenty Dollar condition slightly higher or similar, not One Dollar, so increased improvisation in One Dollar condition did not account for greater opinion change

Sampling and procedural details: 71 male students recruited from required subject pool; experiment advertised as 'Measures of Performance'; tasks arranged to be uniformly boring; interviewers blind to condition; payment given and later returned after debriefing
Data exclusions: 11 of 71 subjects excluded from analysis for suspicion of deception, refusal to be paid/hired, or admitting they were hired; final analyzed sample: 20 subjects per condition

Conclusion: Experimental results strongly corroborate the cognitive dissonance derivations testedâ€”induced counterattitudinal advocacy produced opinion change, and smaller external justification (one dollar) produced more attitude change than larger justification (twenty dollars)

Limitation: Some subjects were suspicious or refused the task leading to exclusions; monetary reward may limit generalizability; and interpretation depends on assumption that tasks were experienced as boring
Assumption: The repetitive tasks used in the experiment were uniformly boring and could create a negative private opinion that could be dissonant with a positive public statement
